message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The ETAPE corpus for the evaluation of speech-based TV content processing in the French language
Paper Abstract: International audience
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing"},{"title":"History of natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_natural_language_processing"},{"title":"Outline of natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_natural_language_processing"},{"title":"Semantic decomposition (natural language processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_decomposition_(natural_language_processing)"},{"title":"Category:Tasks of natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Tasks_of_natural_language_processing"},{"title":"Studies in Natural Language Processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Studies_in_Natural_Language_Processing"},{"title":"Category:Natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Natural_language_processing"},{"title":"Category:Natural language processing software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Natural_language_processing_software"},{"title":"Natural Language Processing (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_Language_Processing_(journal)"},{"title":"Quantum natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_natural_language_processing"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Natural Language Processing:

## Overview

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

## Key Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

## Historical Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.(no content)The Transformer architecture was introduced in 2017, which became foundational for modern NLP systems. The concept of large language model (LLM) emerged in late 2010s, where an LLM is a language model trained with self-supervised learning on vast amount of text.

## Modern Applications

In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Speech recognition television"

Links: [{"title":"Text to speech in digital television - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text_to_speech_in_digital_television"},{"title":"Speech recognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_recognition"},{"title":"Smart TV - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Connected_TV"},{"title":"Alicia Beckford Wassink - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alicia_Beckford_Wassink"},{"title":"Speech Recognition & Synthesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_Recognition_&_Synthesis"},{"title":"Voice user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voice_user_interface"},{"title":"Visible Speech - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visible_speech"},{"title":"Timeline of speech and voice recognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_speech_and_voice_recognition"},{"title":"Smart speaker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_display"},{"title":"List of speech recognition software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_speech_recognition_software"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about speech recognition television:

## Speech Recognition in Television

Speech recognition (automatic speech recognition (ASR), computer speech recognition, or speech-to-text (STT)) is a sub-field of computational linguistics concerned with methods and technologies that translate spoken language into text or other interpretable forms.

### Applications in Smart TVs

Some smart TV devices feature interactive natural user interface technologies for navigation controls and other human interaction, including speech recognition for natural language user interfaces.

### Voice User Interfaces for Television

A voice-user interface (VUI) enables spoken human interaction with computers, using speech recognition to understand spoken commands and answer questions.(no content)Voice user interfaces have been added to automobiles, home automation systems, computer operating systems, home appliances like washing machines and microwave ovens, and television remote controls.

### Text-to-Speech in Digital Television

It's worth noting that there's also related technology: Text to speech in digital television refers to digital television products that use speech synthesis (computer-generated speech that "talks" to the end user) to enable access to blind or partially sighted people.

Speech recognition technology continues to be integrated into modern televisions and remote controls as a way to improve user interaction and accessibility.

Web search results for query: "Corpus linguistics"

Links: [{"title":"Corpus linguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corpus_linguistics"},{"title":"International Journal of Corpus Linguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Journal_of_Corpus_Linguistics"},{"title":"Corpus Linguistics and Linguistic Theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corpus_Linguistics_and_Linguistic_Theory"},{"title":"Category:Corpus linguistics journals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Corpus_linguistics_journals"},{"title":"Law and Corpus Linguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_and_Corpus_Linguistics"},{"title":"Corpus of Linguistic Acceptability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corpus_of_Linguistic_Acceptability"},{"title":"Paul Baker (linguist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Baker_(linguist)"},{"title":"Mark Davies (linguist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Davies_(linguist)"},{"title":"Susan Hunston - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Susan_Hunston"},{"title":"Word list - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Word_list"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of corpus linguistics:

## Definition

Corpus linguistics is an empirical method for the study of language by way of a text corpus (plural corpora).(no content)Corpora are balanced, often stratified collections of authentic, "real world", text of speech or writing that aim to represent a given linguistic variety.

## Applications

Corpora have a wide range of applications. Corpora have not only been used for linguistics research, they have been increasingly used to compile dictionaries (starting with The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language in 1969) and reference grammars, with A Comprehensive Grammar of the English Language, published in 1985, as a first.(no content)A word list is compiled by lexical frequency analysis within a given text corpus, and is used in corpus linguistics to investigate genealogies and evolution of languages and texts.

## Historical Development

A landmark in modern corpus linguistics was the publication of Computational Analysis of Present-Day American English in 1967. Written by Henry Kučera and W. Nelson Francis, the work was based on an analysis of the Brown Corpus, which is a structured and balanced corpus of one million words of American English from the year 1961.

## Modern Applications

Corpus linguistics has also found specialized applications in other fields. For example, Law and corpus linguistics (LCL) is an academic sub-discipline that uses large databases of examples of language usage equipped with tools designed by linguists called corpora to better get at the meaning of words and phrases in legal texts (statutes, constitutions, contracts, etc.).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Corpus linguistics has also found specialized applications in other fields. For example, Law and corpus linguistics (LCL) is an academic sub-discipline that uses large databases of examples of language usage equipped with tools designed by linguists called corpora to better get at the meaning of words and phrases in legal texts (statutes, constitutions, contracts, etc.).
